awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: von Neumann Algebras Associated to Groups Acting on Hyperbolic Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of von Neumann algebras was initiated in the 1930s and 1940s by F. Murray and J. von Neumann as a mathematical tool to understand particle physics. Subsequently, it became an independent discipline that has stimulated the development of powerful mathematical theories and bringing valuable insight to physics (statistical mechanics), biology (DNA structure), and engineering (cell phone network design). Von Neumann algebras are highly interdisciplinary in nature as they arise canonically from simpler mathematical structures, such as symmetries and actions, often present in many areas of mathematics. Over time their study remained closely connected with various topics in dynamical systems, measured group theory, and more recently geometric group theory. This project investigates several major open problems inspired by the rich interaction between operator algebras and the aforementioned fields.

This research project explores new horizons in the classification of group von Neumann algebras. The first objective of the project is to advance Connes' rigidity conjecture, a major wide-open problem predicting that ICC property (T) groups are completely recognizable from their von Neumann algebras (W*-superrigid). The PIs proposed several natural constructions of W*-superrigid property (T) groups based on new developments in geometric group theory and deformation/rigidity theory. The second objective of the project revolves around the study of prime II1 factors. The main focus is to understand the relationship between various manifestations of negative curvature in group theory and primeness aspects of the corresponding group factor. The results arising from this project are expected to reveal significant cross-pollination between, geometric group theory, ergodic theory, random walks, C*-algebras, and von Neumann algebras. The PIs intend to organize a series of workshops aimed at stimulating collaboration between experts in these fields. To promote the career development of graduate students the proposal also involves a student exchange program between the participating institutions aimed at exposing students to different expertise and research environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In a classic paper from the 1940's, Murray and von Neumann observed that every countable discrete group gives rise to a von Neumann algebra in a natural way. Ever since, the study of von Neumann algebras associated to groups has been a central theme in the subject. This interdisciplinary proposal revolved around several major problems inspired by the interaction between operator algebras, group theory, metric geometry, and dynamical systems. Each of the PIs brought a unique perspective and expertise to the project.

Intellectual merit.

The first main goal of this project was to make progress on Connes' rigidity conjecture. This is a problem of major current interest in operator algebras which predicts that infinite property (T) groups are W*-superrigid, i.e., they can be entirely reconstructed from their von Neumann algebras. In the last few years, there have been several exciting developments in Popa's deformation/rigidity theory which have introduced new methods and ideas to tackle classification problems for group von Neumann algebras. The research in this proposal capitalized on these advances in order to provide the first examples of W*-superrigid property (T) groups. 

The second major problem considered in this proposal was related to tensor products of von Neumann algebras. We focus on II_1 factors, a special type of von Neumann algebras whose main source of examples are von Neumann algebras associated to groups with infinite conjugacy classes. A II$_1$ factor is called prime if it cannot be written as a nontrivial tensor product of more than one II_1 factor. Even the existence of such objects, which can be thought of as ``continuous primes", is a highly non-trivial result; the first separable examples were constructed by Ge in 1996 using Voiculescu's free probability theory. A significant generalizatoin of primeness was found by Ozawa in 2004 when he gave examples of II_1 factors having all nonamenable subfactors prime. The research from this grant showed that Ozawa's results could be put in a larger more systematic setting, giving rise to many more examples of this phenomenon. 

Ideas from metric geometry come to the project through the notion of a hyperbolic space introduced by Gromov in 1980s. He suggested that groups acting ``nicely" on hyperbolic spaces should have properties similar to those of free groups and fundamental groups of closed hyperbolic manifolds. Gromov's philosophy has been implemented in the rich theory of hyperbolic and relatively hyperbolic groups. A further development of these ideas, initiated in recent papers by Osin and his co-authors, is instrumental in our approach to the above mentioned-problems on group von Neumann algebras.

Broader Impacts.

The PIs have been heavily involved in training of graduate students and postdocs. Through this grant the PIs participated in a student exchange program allowing PhD students from one university (e.g., Vanderbilt University) to visit another university (e.g., UCSD or University of Iowa) in order to be exposed to a new research environment and interact with researchers having a different expertise than that available at their home institutions.  These visits were highly beneficial to the students' professional development, helping them understand a deeper connection between these areas. 

The PIs also organized a series of workshops, which brought together researchers with expertise in dynamical systems, operator algebras, and group theory. These workshops helped stimulate collaboration between researchers working in these areas and contributed to educating graduate students and young researchers through invited survey lectures on selected subjects related to the project.
